subject: Re: [junit] How can I test async callbacks?
msgSnippet: ... The problem is the callback may execute in a different Thread than the testIt method. That means if the callback calls assert(
messageBody:
--- Joi Ellis <joi@...> wrote:
>Here's what my first try at a callback test would look like. I've<BR>
>never written one before, and I have nothing here to try this on.<BR>

The problem is the callback may execute in a different Thread than the
testIt method. That means if the callback calls assert(<some false
expression) or fail(), the Error gets thrown, but not caught by the
JUnit framework (because it is thrown on the stack of a different
Thread). Having the callback be within the TestCase is not enough to
solve this, it is not a class problem it is a stack/thread problem.

The way we wound up dealing with it for our aynchronous callbacks is by
creating way to configure our code to make the callbacks in the same
thread under certain circumstances. By happy coincidence this same
mechanism is also used to handle many of the differences between our
various platforms. We run most of our tests against the non-threaded
"Test" platform and only run a few threading-specific tests in the more
complicated environments. Those tests have been much harder to write
and I would love good suggestions. Most of them have testFoo method
that end something like this (from memory, probably with typos):

// Wait for asynchronous operations to complete, fail if they don't
try {
asynchObject.wait(ASYNC_TIMEOUT);
}
catch (InterruptedException e) {
fail("Aynchronous operations did not complete in time");
}

Regards,

Rob
